title: Chapter 7 bankruptcy. Filing 7 and want to surrender my mobile home. So what about the money owed for the space rent?
question: So I am in default already on my mortgage for the mobile and am ok with walking away from it. But what I don't know is how the private company whom I pay space rent to separately from my mortgage works in this whole deal. Will I need to keep paying them to allow me more time before the mortgage forecloses? Will the mortgage company take over the space rent obligation to protect their collateral.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure
answers: File a Chapter 7 bankruptcy surrender the mobile home to the secured creditor and list the lease and reject it. Once you file the bankruptcy you will need to vacate the space or you may be liable for the post-petition rent. If you continue to occupy the space after the filing you will need to pay the monthly rent.

The debt to the lender and the mobile home park will be discharged. Be sure you have everything planned out before you file. That would include not living in the mobile home. Debts incurred after you file would not be discharged.
You need to talk to a bankruptcy attorney to help you. There are pitfalls that can be avoided and will save you more than the cost of an attorney.

Always discuss with your ch 7 attorney which apparently you have not chosen to employ one. If not, still meet with one..its usually free with most attorneys.

The lease and the secured debt will be both discharged. But are you liable for anything post petition? What if someone takes over the home and gets hurt after you file and before it is repod? Maybe you can discuss with the creditor if they will pay you $500 for a voluntary transfer of title back to them to help them avoid having to repossess it etc. Call and ask them. Meanwhile, there are other issues and facts that can substantially and gravely affect your case which is why all of us will tell you the same: employ an attorney. Here are some of those other issues!

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

If you have an attorney for your Bankruptcy, then you need to direct your questions to the attorney. If you are not represented by counsel, you should be. You need to retain experienced CA mortgage foreclosure and bankruptcy counsel. Only a mortgage foreclosure and bankruptcy attorney has the expertise to prevent you from having more problems than you can possibly imagine. To properly answer your questions and address your concerns, the best way to handle this is with an in-person consultation with an experienced CA mortgage foreclosure defense and bankruptcy attorney.
